caption: Table 1: Fine-tuning results. LLM performance on the test splits of math, coding and reasoning. Normalized scores are in the parentheses.
description: This table presents the fine-tuning results for three different large language models (LLMs): LLAMA3-8B-INSTRUCT, MISTRAL-7B-INSTRUCT-V0.3, and LLAMA3-70B-INSTRUCT.  For each LLM, it shows the performance on three downstream tasks (GSM8K, MBPP-Pro, and ARC-Easy), comparing the performance of the original, untrained LLM to the same LLM after fine-tuning with either the LoRA method or the authors' proposed Singular Value Fine-tuning (SVF) method.  The scores are normalized relative to the original LLM's performance on each task, providing a direct comparison of the effectiveness of different fine-tuning techniques.  Parenthesized values indicate normalized scores.

caption: Table 2: Self-adaptation on unseen tasks. Normalized scores are in the parentheses.
description: This table presents the results of applying the Transformer² model to four unseen tasks: MATH, Humaneval, ARC-Challenge, and OKVQA.  The performance of the Transformer² model is compared against a baseline LLM and the performance of the LLM fine-tuned with LoRA. Three different adaptation strategies within the Transformer² framework are evaluated: prompt-based adaptation, classification expert-based adaptation, and few-shot adaptation.  The table shows the normalized scores (in parentheses) for each method on each task, allowing for a direct comparison of performance across different adaptation strategies and baselines.

caption: Table 3: Time cost of 2-pass inference in prompt adaptation strategy of Transformer2superscriptTransformer2\text{Transformer}^{2}Transformer start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for the entire problem set. 1st to 2nd pass inference time ratios are shown in parentheses.
description: This table presents the time taken for each step in the two-pass inference process of the Transformer² model during prompt adaptation. The first pass involves classifying the task based on the prompt and selecting appropriate expert modules. The second pass uses these selected modules to generate the final answer.  The table shows the time (in seconds) taken for each of these passes, along with the ratio of the time taken for the second pass to the time taken for the first pass, indicating the relative computational cost of answer generation compared to task classification.  The results are broken down by specific tasks.

caption: Table 4: Ablation studies. We fine-tune Llama3-8B-Instruct on the GSM8K training split with different settings and the results on the test split along with zero-shot transfer results on MATH.
description: This table presents ablation study results for the Singular Value Fine-tuning (SVF) method on the GSM8K dataset.  Different configurations are compared, varying the objective function (policy gradient vs. next token prediction), the model modules updated (MLP, attention, or both), and the number of parameters. The impact of these variations on both the GSM8K test set performance and zero-shot transfer performance on the MATH dataset are shown.

caption:
Table 5: Cross-model z𝑧\bm{z}bold_italic_z vector transfer.
Results from transferring the expert vectors trained on Llama3-8B-Instruct to Mistral-7B-Instruct-v0.3 with cross model few-shot adaptation.
description: This table presents the results of an experiment assessing the transferability of expert vectors trained on one large language model (LLaMa3-8B-Instruct) to another (Mistral-7B-Instruct-v0.3).  Specifically, it shows how well the expert vectors, trained using Singular Value Fine-tuning (SVF) and reinforcement learning (RL) on various tasks (GSM8K, MBPP-Pro, ARC-Easy), perform when applied to the Mistral model. The experiment uses a few-shot adaptation strategy, incorporating a combination of these pre-trained expert vectors.  The results highlight the effectiveness of the method, demonstrating the ability to successfully transfer knowledge across different LLM architectures.

caption: Table 6: Hyper-parameters used for SVF and LoRA training. We perform a sweep on certain sensitive hyper-parameters across methods for fair comparison.
description: This table details the hyperparameters used in training both Singular Value Fine-tuning (SVF) and Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) models.  It shows the initial values and ranges explored for key parameters such as learning rate, batch size, and regularization strength. A sweep was conducted across different settings for a fair comparison between SVF and LoRA.

caption: Table 7: Additional Comparison Experiment. Normalized scores are in the parentheses.
description: This table presents the results of an additional comparison experiment evaluating the performance of different parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) methods on three benchmark tasks: GSM8K, MBPP-Pro, and ARC-Easy.  The experiment compares the performance of the LLAMA3-8B-INSTRUCT model with three PEFT methods: LoRA, IA3, and the proposed SVF method from the paper.  The table shows the raw scores and the normalized scores (in parentheses), allowing for easy comparison of the methods' relative performance across the different tasks.  The goal is to demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed SVF method compared to existing state-of-the-art PEFT techniques.

caption:
Table 9: 
Cross-model z𝑧\bm{z}bold_italic_z Vector Transfer.
Results from transfering the SVF expert vectors trained on Llama3-8B-Instruct to Mistral-7B-Instruct-v0.3 in the respective training tasks.
description: This table presents the results of an experiment assessing the transferability of Singular Value Fine-tuning (SVF) expert vectors.  Specifically, it shows how well SVF vectors trained on the LLAMA3-8B-INSTRUCT model perform when transferred and applied to the MISTRAL-7B-INSTRUCT-V0.3 model. The performance is measured across three tasks: GSM8K, MBPP-pro, and ARC-Easy, representing the original tasks used to train the SVF vectors. This demonstrates cross-model compatibility and the generalizability of the SVF approach.

content:
Method ARC-Challenge
Llama3-8B-Instruct 80.63 (1.00)
   + CEM 10-shot adaptation 82.61 (1.02)
   + CEM 3-shot (30% of prompts) 82.18 (1.02)
   + CEM light (3% of prompts) 82.08 (1.02)
caption: Table 10: 3-shot and light variants Performance with different inference-time adaptation budgets.
description: This table presents the performance of three variants of the Transformer² model on the ARC-Challenge task, each with a different inference-time adaptation budget. The first variant uses the standard 10-shot CEM approach, which involves using 10 samples for CEM-based adaptation. The second variant is a 3-shot approach, using only 3 samples which represents 30% of the samples originally used. The third and final variant, referred to as 'CEM light', only uses 3% of the original samples, making it extremely efficient. The table demonstrates that even with significantly reduced inference-time adaptation budgets, the performance of the model remains strong. This showcases the scalability and efficiency of the proposed approach, emphasizing its ability to maintain high performance while minimizing resource consumption.
